215.91.text:
I think they'll look back and try and explain

219.10.text:
I think partly they'll go, in the way we look

223.20.text:
what happened afterwards – so they'll see

228.13.text:

232.68.text:

235.54.text:
You know, it's almost good to adopt a kind
of historian's perspective to look at the

239.37.text:
grand sweep of history because when you look
back in time, you look back at phenomenon,

244.48.text:
which are... you know, things happening which
are very troubling but we try and understand

250.58.text:
So, if you take Nazism – I'm not comparing
all those things I've just said to Nazism,

253.76.text: incidentally, I'm just using an extreme example.

256.41.text:
So, we look back at Nazism and we don't just
go; 'well, everyone just went mad in Germany.'

261.21.text: You know, we don't do that.

262.58.text:
We go; 'well, there was the calamitous defeat
Germany suffered in World War One, the Treaty

267.92.text:
of Versailles, which imposed punitive, you
know, punishment against Germany where you

273.58.text:
then had mass inflation and then, in the 1920s
you've got the rise of a far right movement

279.24.text:
which was then well positioned to exploit
the discontent that occurred.

283.62.text:
That's how we understand it and I think it's
important to do that, even with things like

288.64.text:
Similarly, if you take another extreme example:
Islamist fundamentalism.

293.77.text:
Now, some people just go; 'well, it's just
an evil ideology, people are brainwashed.'

297.19.text:
But, I find that odd because we don't just...
We don't with Nazism just go; 'evil ideology,

304.15.text:
That would be such a simplistic way of looking
at things. So, you know, I think what we have

307.56.text:
to do, in terms of Islamist fundamentalism,
is understand why some people become radicalised

314.05.text:
and others obviously don't. That's not the
same for every individual.

317.80.text:
You know, for some, in some parts of the world
it might be some form of economic insecurity.

322.03.text:
It might be frustration at the tyranny that
rules over their country and encountering

326.91.text:
a movement which seems to position itself
as being opposed to it. It might be, part

331.78.text:
of it, anger at western foreign policy merging

336.77.text:
In Britain, you know, you get people going
to Syria who, er, they order Islam for Dummies

342.30.text: on Amazon before they go off.

343.53.text:
And, you know, often they were people who

So, the point I'm making with everything – all

350.73.text:
you really don't like at all – you've got
to understand what they are, why they came

356.52.text:

360.17.text:
You know, understanding isn't justifying even
if it's often distasteful, even if you think;

368.13.text:
'well, all we need to do is condemn these
movements, whatever they are and say nothing

374.32.text:
else, that's justifying them.' I don't agree
with that.
